@about(Barty Beauregard)

On March 14, 1903, Barty Beauregard met Mildred Finch beneath the old clock tower in Wickersham Square. 
The tower had been abandoned since the Great Fire of 1887, but Barty believed something within its gears 
still marked the hours for the dead.

[[Entity: Barty Beauregard|type=PERSON]] carried his silver pocket watch, a gift from [[Entity: Frederick Holloway|type=PERSON]], 
and noted that it ticked perfectly in sync with the tower's broken hands. Mildred, ever cautious, warned him that 
the clock had struck thirteen once before — on the night Frederick vanished.

Later that evening, Barty recorded in his journal that he had seen a faint green light pulse behind the tower’s face. 
He wrote, “The sound was like breathing.” [[Entity: Melora Graves|type=PERSON]] later confirmed seeing the same glow 
from her window at [[Entity: Thornbridge House|type=PLACE]].

By dawn, the clock tower stood silent again. Yet witnesses swore that the second hand trembled, as if resisting the dawn.
